Object-orientation Scheme

Dan Kelley (https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7808-5911)

2021-06-05

Source: vignettes/object_orientation.Rmd
object_orientation.Rmd

The S3 scheme is used for objects created by functions in the mooring package. These objects inherit from the "mooring" class. The contents consist of a list that in turn contains one or more lists.

The elementary functions, [anchor()], [chain()], [wire()] and [float()], produce objects with main class "mooring" and sub-class with the function name. The contents vary from subclass to subclass. For example, a discrete object like an anchor or a float has a certain buoyancy, so that is saved in a field called buoyancy that has units of kg (converted from Newtons by dividing by the acceleration due to gravity). However, a wire’s buoyancy field in units of kg/m, representing buoyancy per length. Another difference relates to size. Following Dewey’s convention, a float is stored with a diameter, whereas a wire or a chain is stored with a width. Allowances for these different aspects are made in [knockdown()], as it computes drag and buoyancy forces on elements.

For example,

library(mooring)
m <- mooring(anchor(depth=100), wire(length=75), float())

produces a list with 3 elements, one that holds information on the anchor, a second that holds information on the wire, and a third that holds information on the float.

Developed by Dan Kelley.
